title-group.article-title: Processing and characterization of solid and foamed injection-molded polylactide with talc

article-meta.aff: Microcellular Plastics Manufacturing Laboratory, Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering, University of Toronto, 5 King’s College Road, Toronto, Ontario, Canada

author-notes.corresp: Chul B. Park, Microcellular Plastics Manufacturing Laboratory, Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering, University of Toronto, 5 King’s College Road, Toronto, Ontario, Canada M5S 3G8. Email: park@mie.utoronto.ca

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Polylactide (PLA) suffers from poor processability due to its low melt strength and slow crystallization kinetics and it is thus very challenging to achieve uniformly distributed fine-celled PLA foams with high void fractions in injection molding process. In this work, the low-pressure structural foam molding of linear PLA with a relatively high void fraction of ∼30% was conducted and by fine tuning the talc content and the foaming and processing parameters, a relatively uniform fine-celled structure with improved cell size and cell density was successfully produced. The effects of twin-screw compounding and the addition of talc on the foaming behavior, structural uniformity, crystallinity, and mechanical properties of the solid and foamed PLA samples were investigated. The results showed that the addition of 5 wt.% talc significantly improved the foaming properties such as cell density, cell size, structural uniformity, and consequently improved the mechanical properties of foams. The twin-screw compounding before injection molding did not significantly change the foaming behavior, but adversely affected the mechanical properties of the solid and foamed PLA samples due to mechanical and thermal degradation. The changes in the mechanical properties were discussed in terms of the crystallinity, talc toughening effect, and foam quality.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Polylactide (PLA) is a biobased, biodegradable, and biocompatible aliphatic polyester. Due to its unique set of properties, it has many applications in the packaging, biomedical, pharmaceutical, and structural fields.1–5 As a biobased polymer, PLA is made from renewable resources such as corn. It can be naturally recycled by biological processes, thereby reducing society’s dependency on depleting fossil fuels. By extension, it could help in the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions. Although PLA has these environmental advantages, it also has inferior properties such as poor melt strength, brittleness, a narrow processing window, and sensitivity to moisture and heat.6 To broaden PLA’s applications, its properties and processing ability must be improved. The final cost of the products must also be taken into account.

Fine-celled injection foam molding introduces such advantages as less material usage, greater dimensional stability, a shorter cycle time, and less energy consumption. At the same time, it can potentially improve some mechanical properties such as fatigue life and impact strength.7–15 High-pressure microcellular injection molding is widely used in structural foaming. Cell nucleation and coalescence control in high-pressure injection molding both with and without mold opening are relatively easy.10–12 But this technology is limited only to the void fractions of 5–15%. To achieve void fractions greater than 20% without using mold opening technology, low-pressure structural foam molding technology is used. In contrast to high-pressure structural foaming, it is very challenging to control the foaming properties of cell nucleation, growth, and coalescence in low-pressure structural foam molding technology with a short shot. The foam’s structural uniformity, high cell density, and small cell sizes are not easily achieved for a relatively high void fraction of over 20% without mold opening.10–12 With its well-known low melt strength and slow crystallization kinetics,6 it is even more difficult to uniformly foam PLA in low-pressure structural foam molding. To achieve uniformly distributed fine-celled PLA foams in low-pressure structural foaming, the melt strength and the crystallization behavior of the PLA should be improved and the processing window also should be carefully identified.

Substantial research has been conducted on injection foam molding and characterization for many different plastics. Yet, there has been limited research in these areas for PLA. Recently, some workers have tried the high-pressure structural foaming of PLA.6,15–20 It has been shown that the addition of nanoclay16,17,19 and chain extender6 improves the foaming behavior of PLA by enhancing the melt strength and increasing cell nucleation power. Pilla et al.18 have also reported that the average cell size decreases while the cell density and degree of PLA crystallinity increase with the fiber content in the injection-molded PLA/flax fiber composites. However, all these works are focused on the high-pressure injection foam molding with relatively low void fraction.

In the injection molding of PLA, most of the literature refers to the properties of as received PLA as a baseline when dealing with composites, compounds, or blends of PLA.6,16,17,19 The majority of these material systems were, however, prepared by an aggressive compounding process. This can reduce the molecular weight of PLA due to the thermal and mechanical degradation that occurs during compounding.20,21 It has also been reported that the thermal history significantly affects PLA’s crystallization behavior.22 Recently, Pantani et al. studied the crystallization kinetics of as received and processed PLA. They showed that it changes after regular extrusion and injection-molding processes.23 Such results for as received neat PLA can therefore be of very limited use or even misleading for processed PLA compounds.

Low-pressure injection foam molding has been previously used for various thermoplastic foams such as polyethylene, polypropylene, and thermoplastic polyolefin to achieve relatively high void fraction with incomplete mold filling and without using mold opening technique.8,10–12,24,25 However, the low-pressure injection foam molding of PLA is much more challenging compared with these relatively foamable resins due to PLA’s weak melt strength and it has not been extensively studied.

In this study, we tried to find the processing window which can lead to the production of PLA/talc composite foams with uniformly distributed fine cells and a high void fraction in a low-pressure structural foaming system with partial filling. The effects of talc as a cell nucleating agent on the cell morphology, structural uniformity, crystallization behavior, and mechanical properties of PLA foams were studied. Three different solid and foamed material systems were investigated: as received neat PLA (PLA-A), processed neat PLA (PLA-P), and PLA processed with 5 wt.% talc (PLA-T). This was undertaken to decouple the effects of the compounding process and the addition of talc on the foaming properties, crystallization behavior, and tensile properties. The effects of annealing after injection molding on the crystallinity and tensile properties of the solid and foamed samples were further investigated.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Injection grade PLA, Ingeo™ 3001D, was supplied by NatureWorks® LLC, Minnetonka, MN, USA. It was in pellet form and had a specific gravity of 1.24 g/cm3, a melt flow index of around 15 g/10 min. (190℃/2.16 kg), and 1.4% of d-lactide molar content. For the nucleating agent, talc, grade Cimpact CB710, provided by Luzenac was used. It had a density of 2.8 g/cm3 and an average particle size of 1.7 µm. Nitrogen (N2), supplied by Linde Gas Canada, was employed as the environmentally benign blowing agent.

sec.title: Preparation of compounds
sec.p:
Prior to compounding and dry blending, PLA pellets were oven dried at 65℃ for at least 6 h to remove any excess moisture. PLA with 5 wt.% talc (PLA-T) was then compounded using an intermeshing and co-rotating twin-screw extruder with a screw diameter of 30 mm [Werner & Pfleiderer ZSK-30, length/diameter (L/D) = 38:1]. The compounding temperature and screw speed were 170℃ and 40 rpm, respectively. In order to decouple the sole effects of the compounding process and the addition of talc, the neat PLA was also compounded without talc (PLA-P) using the identical processing conditions as used for the PLA-T compound (Table 1). Table 1.
Compounding conditions of three different materials.
Temperature (℃) Screw speed (rpm) Talc content (wt.%)
PLA-A N/A N/A N/A
PLA-P 170 40 0
PLA-T 170 40 5

sec.title: Experimental setup
sec.p:
A 50-ton Arburg Allrounder 270/320 C injection molding machine (Lossburg, Germany) with a 30-mm diameter screw was used to conduct the experiments. The mold contained a rectangular cavity with a fan gate after the sprue (Figure 1). The cavity dimensions were 152.4 mm× 101.6 mm× 3.2 mm. More details about the mold can be found in Lee et al.12 Table 2 summarizes the processing parameters used in the injection molding of solid and foamed samples. It is noted that the processing parameters were first optimized by a series of trial and error experiments. This was done to minimize the processing temperature, and thus reduce the thermal degradation of PLA, and also to achieve relatively similar pressure profiles within the cavity at three different locations: near the gate and at the middle and end of the samples (Figure 1). Similar pressure profiles at different locations were very important to achieve uniform foam morphology along the sample. The injection flow rate affected the pressure profiles significantly and was a very effective parameter for foaming, and thus four different injection flow rates (15, 25, 50, and 100 cm3/s) were studied. For the selected processing temperature of 170℃, a melt pressure of 17 MPa was chosen to ensure that it was sufficiently higher than the solubility pressure for the 0.6 wt.% N2 injected into the polymer melt.26 Figure 1.
Side view of the injection-molded part and the configuration of the pressure transducers. A, B, and C denote the end, middle, and near the gate of the samples, respectively.
Table 2.
Processing parameters used in the injection molding of solid and foamed samples.
Injection molding parameter Solid Foam
Nozzle temperature (℃) 170 170
Barrel temperature (℃) 170 170
Feed throat temperature (℃) 40 40
Feed temperature (℃) 145 145
Mold temperature (℃) 25 25
Screw speed (rpm) 400 400
Metering time (s) 8 8
Gas injection pressure (MPa) N/A 24
N2 wt.% content (%) N/A 0.6
Set void fraction (%) N/A 25
Pack/hold pressure (MPa) 80 N/A
Pack/hold time (s) 6 N/A

The mold cavity pressures were measured near the gate, at the middle of the cavity, and near the end of the cavity, during the entire injection cycle using three PT462E Dynisco pressure transducers and a DAQ board (Compact DAQ Kit, National Instruments). The pressure transducers were located in the inserted mold, so that they flush-mounted along the filling direction in the longitudinal centerline of the cavity (Figure 1).

sec.title: Foam characterization
sec.p: To measure the local void fraction, the foam density (ρf) was first measured using the water-displacement method (ASTM D792-00). The expansion ratio (Φ) was calculated as the ratio of the bulk density of the samples (ρ0) and the measured density of the foam sample. The local void fraction was subsequently determined as follows12: (1)avoid fraction=(1-1Φ).

To measure the cell size and density, the samples were first dipped in liquid nitrogen and then fractured to expose their cellular morphology. The fractured surfaces were then sputter coated with platinum to enhance their conductivity. The microstructures were examined using a JEOL JSM-6060 scanning electron microscope (SEM). Image processing was carried out using ImageJ software by the National Institutes of Health, USA. The local cell density was calculated from the SEM micrographs and by using the following equation12: (2)cell density=(nM2A)3/2(11-avoid fraction), where n is the number of voids in the micrograph, and A and M are the area and magnification factor of the micrograph. For each part, the void fraction and cell density were measured at three different locations: near the gate and at the middle and end of the sample, same locations where the pressure was recorded (Figure 1), but with a slight distance from the longitudinal centerline.

sec.title: Differential scanning calorimetry
sec.p: The final crystallinity of the solid and foamed injected samples was explored by running a first heating cycle in a differential scanning calorimeter (DSC) using a DSC Q2000 (TA Instrument, USA). The samples were heated from room temperature to 200℃ at a heating rate of 10℃/min. During all the heating processes, the DSC curves were recorded and analyzed using TA Universal software. The final degree of crystallinity was then calculated using the following equation27: (3)crystallinity=((ΔHm-ΔHcc)93.6)×100%, where ΔHm and ΔHcc are the melting enthalpy and the cold crystallization enthalpy, respectively, and 93.6 is the melting enthalpy in J/g of 100% crystalline PLA.27

The effects of annealing on the crystallization behavior of the PLA samples were also explored using the DSC. The samples were heated up to 90℃ at a rate of 10℃/min followed by 60 min of annealing. The samples were then cooled at a rate of 20℃/min to room temperature. The final crystallinity of the PLA samples after annealing was calculated using the heating graphs after heating the samples to 200℃ at a rate of 10℃/min.

sec.title: Tensile testing
sec.p: The ASTM D638-03 was adopted for the static tensile testing of the solid and foamed samples. The specimen geometry of Type IV was chosen and cut from the injection-molded samples, parallel to the samples’ longitudinal centerline with a slight distance from the center. A die cutter under compression molding was used to cut the specimens. The tensile tests were conducted at room temperature (∼25℃) and atmospheric conditions (relative humidity of ∼50 ± 5%) with a 10-kN load cell on an Instron tensile tester. The crosshead speed was set at 5 mm/min. Five replications were tested for each condition, and the average values and their standard deviations are reported. Toughness was obtained by integrating the area under the stress–strain curve. The specific values of stress, strength, modulus, and toughness were obtained by dividing their measured values by the density of the test specimen.

To assess the effect of annealing on the tensile properties of the injection-molded samples, the tensile bars were annealed by placing them inside a temperature-controlled oven at 90℃ for 60 min. They were then removed from the oven and cooled down to room temperature before tensile testing. The DSC results showed that 60 min of annealing at 90℃ was sufficient for the samples to fully crystallize.

sec.title: Effects of compounding and addition of talc on cell morphology
sec.p:
Figure 2 shows the representative SEM micrographs of the injected foams of (a) PLA-A, (b) PLA-P, and (c) PLA-T. Overall, three different regions were observed in the morphology across the samples’ thickness. These were the skin layer, the transition region, and the core region, which were identified as S, T, and C, respectively, in Figure 2. The skin layer presented a solid unfoamed structure, and its thickness remained approximately unchanged for PLA-A, PLA-P, and PLA-T at a given injection flow rate. The skin layer thickness was governed mainly by the cooling rate. Cavity pressure measurements showed very similar pressure profiles for these three materials under identical processing conditions. This indicated that the difference in their viscosity caused by processing or by the addition of 5 wt.% talc was not sufficient to change the melt flow pattern inside the cavity. Thus, the cooling rate was not significantly affected. Therefore, the difference in the cooling rate of these materials that were injection molded under the same conditions did not result in different skin layer thicknesses. Both the transition and core regions possessed a cellular structure, but with different cell morphologies. The major difference between the core and transition regions was the degree of cell elongation, which was much more severe in the transition region. Figure 2.
Representative SEM micrographs of injected foams of (a) as received PLA, (b) processed PLA and (c) PLA processed with 5 wt.% talc. Micrographs were taken from the side view at the middle of the samples (location B at Figure 1). The upper micrographs show the half-thickness cross-section, with the skin layer located at the top. The horizontal lines divide the cross-section into skin layer, transition region, and core region, denoted as S, T, and C, respectively. The middle and lower micrographs show the higher magnification of morphology at the core and transition regions, respectively (injection flow rate: 50 cm3/s).

Figure 2(a) and (b) shows that the cell morphology was similar for both the received and the processed PLA foams. The injection-molded samples had an approximately 500 µm of skin layer thickness and a region of 500 -µm thick next to the skin layer was considered as the transition region. The cells were elongated at both the core and transition regions, with a greater degree of severity in the transition region. This similarity indicated that the compounding procedure before injection molding had no significant effect on the PLA’s foaming behavior. However, the cell morphology changed after the talc was added. In the core region, the cells were relatively uniform in size and in distribution and retained their spherical shape during cell growth. Two types of cells were observed in the transition region: (a) very fine cells with relatively spherical shapes and (b) large cells that had been elongated in the melt flow direction, and which were similar to those in the neat PLA but had much smaller aspect ratios (Figure 2(c)). It is believed that with the absence of talc, the PLA’s poor cell nucleating ability and relatively low melt strength coupled with the relatively high shear rates during the melt flow inside the cavity adversely affected the foaming behavior. This resulted in highly elongated cells in the direction of the melt flow throughout the part thickness between the two skin layers. Cell coalescence also occurred occasionally and created some very long and relatively large cells. However, the addition of 5 wt.% talc increased both the cell nucleation ability and the melt strength. In this condition, a larger number of cell nuclei could be created and gently grow, especially in the core region, where the shear effect was lower than that in the transition region. A significant number of cells in the transition region also retained their spherical shape. However, some highly elongated cells were observed in this region. This situation might be further improved by increasing the talc content and, therefore, the melt strength.

Figure 3(a) and (b) shows the cell density and cell size of PLA-A, PLA-P, and PLA-T foams. Even though some cells were severely elongated in the transition region, the cell density of the transition region was roughly also measured using the same method as for the spherical cells of the core in order to be able to compare the results of different materials. Within the entire text, the error bars show± 1 standard deviation. Overall, the cell density was slightly higher in the transition region than in the core. One reason for this difference could be that the transition region was filled and formed earlier than the core region. Thus, the pressure drop was higher which, in turn, resulted in a greater number of cell nuclei. As shown in Figure 3(a) and (b), the cell density and cell size did not markedly change with the addition of the compounding step, as had happened in the overall foam structure (Figure 2). The added talc, however, increased the cell density by approximately an order of magnitude and decreased the average cell size from about 100 µm to 30 µm. Furthermore, the addition of talc significantly improved the uniformity of cell size, as shown in Figure 4. The cell size ranged from 10 µm to 250 µm for PLA-A while the range shrank to 10–70 µm in PLA-T foams. The cell size distribution remained approximately unchanged after the compounding step (PLA-P). Figure 3.
(a) Cell density and (b) cell size of PLA-A, PLA-P, and PLA-T measured at the middle of the samples.
Figure 4.
Cell size distribution in the PLA-A and PLA-T foams measured in the middle of the samples.

Figure 5 shows the local void fraction at the middle location of the PLA-A, PLA-P, and PLA-T foams. The T-test analysis showed that the differences between the average void fraction values were not statistically significant at a 95% confidence interval. This was expected since the void fraction was controlled mainly by the set void fraction and the injection processing parameters that were the same for all of the foams. It is noted that the measured local void fractions were higher than the set void fraction. If the void fractions of the sprue, runner, and injection-molded parts had been uniform, the measured void fraction from the molded part would have been the same as the set void fraction. However, the void fractions of the spure, runner, and gate were lower than those of the injection-molded part itself, as also reported in Lee and Park.11 This must have been caused by the pressure in the sprue and runner that was much higher than the pressure in the mold cavity. Consequently, the local void fraction of the injection-molded parts became higher than the set void fraction (Figure 5). Figure 5.
Local void fraction of PLA-A, PLA-P, and PLA-T measured in the middle of the samples.

sec.title: Effect of injection flow rate on cell morphology
sec.p:
Figure 6 shows the SEM micrographs of PLA-T foams molded with different injection flow rates. With the increased injection flow rate, the cells started to distribute more uniformly in terms of size and location. Also, as seen in Figure 7, the higher injection flow rates resulted in smaller cell sizes and greater cell densities. Increasing the injection flow rate from 15 cm3/s to 100 cm3/s reduced the average cell size from 61 ± 20 µm to 17 ± 11 µm and increased the cell density from 5.7 × 106 ± 1.0 × 106cells/cm3 to 1.2 × 108 ± 1.4 × 107cells/cm3. The injection flow rate effect can be explained in terms of the melt cooling and the cavity pressure during the injection. The degree to which the melt cooled varied with the injection flow rate. A higher injection flow rate reduced the cooling rate during injection, which resulted in a lower melt viscosity and increased the mixture’s ability to flow. In addition, because the melt temperature was high, the time for cell nucleation and growth was longer at a high injection flow rate. Furthermore, the maximum pressure inside the cavity decreased with the increased injection flow rate. This would have been resulted in greater pressure drop rate during the injection and consequently larger number of cell nuclei. Therefore, higher injection flow rate provided a circumstance where a larger number of cell nuclei could grow in the matrix that had increased flowability. This resulted in spherical cells with a greater cell density and smaller cell sizes, specifically, at the core which was hotter than the transition region. The effect of the injection flow rate on foaming is further discussed in Section 3.2.2. The local void fraction measured at the middle of the samples did not significantly change with the increase in injection flow rate. Figure 6.
Representative SEM micrographs of PLA-T foams made with different injection flow rates. Scale bars are 100 µm.
Figure 7.
Average cell size and cell density vs. injection flow rate in PLA-T foams measured at the middle of the samples.

sec.title: Effect of compounding and addition of talc on foam uniformity
sec.p:
Figure 8 shows the SEM micrographs of the core and transition regions at three different locations: near the gate, and at the middle and end of the PLA-T foams injected at an injection flow rate of 50 cm3/s. Due to the longer flow length during the injection and filling periods, cell elongation was more pronounced at the end of the sample in both the core and transition regions. Likewise, near the gate, due to the shortest flow length being there, the shear effects and cell elongation were minimized. Even though some differences were observed in the cell morphology of different locations, the cell density, local void fraction, and pressure profile measurements revealed a noticeable structural uniformity. Figure 8.
Representative SEM micrographs showing the core and transition regions near the gate, and at the middle and end of the PLA-T samples (injection flow rate: 50 cm3/s).

Figures 9 and 10 show the cell density and void fraction measured near the gate and at the middle and end of the PLA-A, PLA-P, and PLA-T foams. For the PLA-T foams, the cell density and void fraction values were found to be relatively similar at different locations in the samples. The T-test analysis revealed that the differences between the cell density and void fraction values at different locations were not statistically significant at a 95% confidence interval. This indicated that the cell structure was statistically uniform throughout the PLA-T samples. For the PLA-A and PLA-P foams, however, there were some differences in the cell density and void fraction at different locations. For the PLA-P specifically, the cell density and void fraction at the sample’s end were found to be relatively lower and higher, respectively, compared with those near the gate and at the middle. Because of the combined effects of the PLA’s poor melt strength and the longer flow length at the sample’s end, there was too much cell growth and thus elongation. Also, some severe coalescence occurred at this location, which resulted in very big cells and, consequently, a lower cell density and a higher void fraction. This might have been caused by the synergistic effect of PLA’s poor melt strength and excessive cell growth at the end location. Similar observations near the gate, middle, and end locations of injection-molded samples have been also reported for other plastics.11 The added talc appeared to increase the PLA’s melt strength and cell nucleating power. Thus, the foam’s overall uniformity was improved. Figure 9.
Cell density of PLA-A and PLA-T foams measured near the gate and at the middle and end of the samples.
Figure 10.
Local void fraction of PLA-A and PLA-T foams measured near the gate and at the middle and end of the samples.
As discussed in Section 3.1.1, the processing step and the added 5 wt.% talc did not significantly affect the thickness uniformity of the foamed samples’ skin layer.

sec.title: Effect of injection flow rate on foam uniformity
sec.p:
It has been reported in the literature that the unfoamed skin layer thickness in injection foam-molded samples is sensitive to the injection flow rate.28 Figure 11 shows the variations in the skin layer thickness, with the injection flow rate, near the gate and at the middle and end of the PLA-T foams. At the lowest injection flow rate, the skin layer thickness was significantly non-uniform and ranged from 680 µm near the gate to 410 µm at the end of the sample. With the increased injection flow rate, the skin layer thickness decreased at all the locations with a greater rate near the gate than at the end of the sample. This trend of change in the skin layer resulted in a fairly uniform distribution of approximately 300 µm of skin layer thickness throughout the samples’ length at the highest injection flow rate (Figure 11). At a higher injection flow rate, the injection and filling time were shorter and thus the temperature difference between different sample’s locations was decreased. This provided a fairly consistent situation in terms of temperature and pressure in different sample’s location and gave the cells the opportunity to nucleate and grow within a greater thickness of the cavity at different locations and resulted in a smaller unfoamed layer in the skin at all the locations. The effect was more pronounced near the gate, where the melt first touched the mold cavity surface and solidified earlier. At a lower injection flow rate, there was more time for the melt to slowly pass through this region. The result was a thicker solid skin. At a high injection flow rate, the time factor was minimized, and the result was a fairly uniform skin layer at the samples’ near gate, middle, and end locations. Figure 11.
Variation of skin layer thickness with injection flow rate measured near the gate and at the middle and end of the PLA-T foam samples.

As Figure 12 shows, at an injection flow rate of 15 cm3/s, the cell density was different by up to four-fold at the samples’ near gate, middle, and end locations. With the increased injection flow rate, however, the difference between the cell density values measured at different locations was reduced, and beyond the injection flow rate of 50 cm3/s, the values were very similar. To achieve final uniform cell morphology, uniform cell nucleation is required throughout the sample. Cell nucleation is controlled by the magnitude of the pressure drop and the pressure drop rate across the gate during the injection.7,12 To quantify the effects of these parameters, the cavity pressure was measured at the samples’ near gate, middle, and end locations (Figure 1). Figure 13 shows the maximum values of the cavity pressures at different injection flow rates in these same locations. With the increased injection flow rate, the pressure near the gate was remarkably decreased, and the pressure distribution within the cavity reached a fairly uniform state. Noting that the other processing parameters and the mold and gate configurations were kept unchanged, similar pressure values at different locations of the samples obtained at high injection flow rates would have resulted in a uniform pressure drop rate during the entire injection cycle. Therefore, the cell nucleation behavior that is governed by the pressure drop and the pressure drop rate7 was expected to be more uniform during the entire injection cycle at higher injection flow rate. Consequently, at a higher injection flow rate, a more uniform cell nucleation and growth resulted in a more uniform foam structure. Figure 12.
Variation of cell density with injection flow rate at the near gate, middle, and end locations of the PLA-T foamed samples.
Figure 13.
Variation of maximum cavity pressure with injection flow rate at the near gate, middle, and end locations of PLA-T foamed samples.

sec.title: Crystallization behavior
sec.p:
Figure 14 shows the final crystallinity for the injected solid and foamed PLA-A, PLA-P, and PLA-T samples. After twin-screw compounding, the amount of crystallinity increased two-fold. It has been shown that PLA is sensitive to processing conditions and a reduction in molecular weight may occur due to the thermal and mechanical degradation that takes place during the processing.21,22,24 It is, therefore, plausible to assume that the mechanical degradation and chain scission caused by the relatively high shear stresses during relatively aggressive twin-screw compounding decreased the molecular weight. Thus, the molecular mobility was increased and the crystallinity was enhanced. Figure 14.
Final crystallinity of injected solid and foamed PLA-A, PLA-P, and PLA-T samples (injection flow rate: 50 cm3/s).

Adding 5 wt.% talc to the compounded PLA samples further increased the crystallinity by about 50%. This amount is noticeable when the very rapid cooling rate of the injection-molding process is considered. Some researchers have shown that talc strongly affects the crystallinity and viscosity of PLA.29–32 For example, Harris and Lee29 found that the isothermal crystallization half-time of PLA at 115℃ was decreased nearly 65-fold by adding 2 wt.% talc. Yu et al.30 also showed that PLA’s crystallinity increased proportionally with talc content. Nofar et al.31 investigated the effect of talc on the thermal properties of PLA and found that shear-induced crystallization during small amplitude oscillatory shearing as well as extensional viscosity of PLA are strongly affected by talc. Moon and Cha33 also studied the viscosity changes with talc in microcellular foaming process and showed that the apparent viscosity increases in the presence of talc.

In most of the literature, the change in crystallinity during the compounding with talc is attributed completely to the talc effect. However, it is very important to note that compounding itself has a significant effect on the PLA’s crystallinity. For example, in this study, more than 50% of the increase in crystallinity was due to the compounding alone (Figure 14). The relatively high shear stresses undergone by the polymer during the injection and filling processes might have also contributed to its relatively high crystallinity through the action of shear-induced crystallinity. It should also be noted that foaming did not appear to significantly affect the samples’ final crystallinity. The difference in the crystallinity values of the corresponding solid and foamed samples was found to be statistically insignificant at a 95% confidence interval.

It is noted that the greater amount of crystallinity in PLA-T samples could have partially contributed to the achievement of foams with large cell density and small cell size by further increasing the melt strength during the foaming. Further study is needed to clarify this effect.

Table 3 lists the crystallinity of the solid and foamed PLA-A, PLA-P, and PLA-T samples before and after the annealing process. The crystallization half-time of the samples’ isothermal cold crystallization is also given in Table 3. In all cases, crystallinity increased after the annealing. Similar results have been reported for PLA or its blends in Takayama et al.34 and Ran et al.35 The final crystallinity of PLA-A was slightly lower than that of PLA-P. This was likely due to the more constrained chain mobility caused by longer chains of unprocessed neat PLA. Table 3.
Effect of annealing on the crystallinity of solid and foamed PLA-A, PLA-P, and PLA-T injected samples.
Before annealing (%) After annealing (%) Crystallization half-time (min)
Solid PLA-A 9.5 35.2 2.9
PLA-P 17.5 42.3 1.8
PLA-T 26.1 41.9 0.9
Foam PLA-A 8.3 34.4 3.2
PLA-P 18.9 42.8 1.6
PLA-T 24.6 40.8 0.8

The final crystallinity after annealing was found to be approximately the same for PLA-P and PLA-T. This can be attributed to their similar processing history and thus their similar molecular structure. As Table 3 shows, the crystallization half-time was decreased by the added talc, indicating that it increased the PLA’s crystallization rate. This can be correlated to the higher crystallinity that the PLA-T samples achieved after injection molding.

sec.title: Effect of compounding and addition of talc on tensile properties
sec.p:
Figure 15 shows the stress–strain curves for solid and foamed PLA-A, PLA-P, and PLA-T. In both solid and foamed PLAs, performing the compounding before the injection molding changed the overall failure behavior of the PLA from a relatively ductile characteristic to a brittle one. However, with the addition of 5 wt.% talc during compounding, the failure behavior resembled that of the as received PLA, that is, relatively ductile in both the solid and foamed cases. Figure 15.
Representative stress–strain curves for solid and foamed PLA-A, PLA-P, and PLA-T samples.

Figure 16(a) and (b) shows the respective variations of the specific tensile strength and modulus of the solid and foamed PLA-A, PLA-P, and PLA-T samples. Overall, the specific strength of the foamed samples was 10–26% lower than that of the corresponding solid samples. To evaluate the sole effect of the added talc, the PLA-P and PLA-T were compared. The strength of the foamed samples increased by 15% with the addition of 5 wt.% talc, so that the difference between the specific tensile strength of the solid and foamed PLA-T samples reached as low as 10%. As seen in Figure 16(b), the specific modulus of the foamed samples was higher than that of their corresponding solid samples, except in the case of processed PLA, which was slightly lower. The compounding process decreased the specific modulus of the as received PLA by about 5%. The addition of the 5 wt.% talc increased the specific modulus of the processed PLA by 15%, resulting in foamed PLA-T samples with a specific modulus that was 17% greater than that of the solid PLA-T sample. Figure 16.
Tensile properties of solid and foamed PLA-A, PLA-P, and PLA-T: (a) specific tensile strength; (b) specific tensile modulus; (c) strain at break, and (d) specific toughness.

Figure 16(c) and (d) show the strain at break and the specific toughness of the PLA-A, PLA-P, and PLA-T. Overall, the foamed samples showed a lower strain at break and a lower specific toughness up to a maximum of 14% and 33%, respectively, compared with their corresponding solid counterparts. The compounding process significantly decreased the strain at break and the specific toughness of both the solid and foamed PLA samples up to 41% and 49%, respectively. However, the addition of talc significantly improved the strain at break and the specific toughness of the processed PLA. For the foamed samples, the strain at break and the specific toughness increased by approximately 60% and 90% with the introduction of 5 wt.% talc.

In the case of PLA-P, increased crystallinity enhanced the strength and modulus while the mechanical degradation during the twin-screw compounding adversely affected them. Thus, it appears that these two factors compensated each other and resulted in approximately unchanged modulus and strength. However, both mechanical degradation and increased crystallinity caused a transition in the failure behavior from ductile to brittle, with a significantly decreased strain at break and lessened specific toughness.

In the case of solid PLA-T, even though the crystallinity was further improved with the added talc, this addition had a more pronounced toughening effect. Thus, the chain mobility was increased and resulted in a slightly lower strength and modulus. The toughening effect of talc significantly improved the strain at break and specific toughness. The reduced constraint caused by the poor interface bonding between the talc particles and the matrix molecules might have also enhanced the chain mobility. In contrast to the solid PLA-T samples, the specific strength and modulus of the foamed PLA-T samples increased by adding talc. The improvement in these properties was attributed to the uniformly distributed fine cells with greater cell density and smaller cell size in the PLA-T foams which differed from those in the PLA-A and PLA-P foams (Figure 2).

Overall, the foamed samples had lower average values for speciﬁc strength, strain at break, and speciﬁc toughness compared with those of the solid ones. This can be attributed to the presence of certain large voids that formed due to the dynamic nature of injection foam molding.6,12 These voids may be much larger than the naturally occurring voids in the solid samples and may become regions of stress concentrations, thereby decreasing the mechanical properties of the foam.6 This was clearly seen in the inferior mechanical properties of the as received and processed neat PLA foams, which had poorer foam properties than the PLA-T samples. By adding talc to the processed PLA, the foamed samples’ mechanical properties were more improved than in the solid samples. This was associated with the more uniform cell morphology of the PLA-T samples, which reduced the number of large voids and resulted in further improved mechanical properties. For the speciﬁc modulus, the foamed PLA-T samples had higher value (17%) than their solid counterparts.

Comparing the specific tensile properties of the neat PLA and PLA with talc, it was seen that the combined effects of compounding and the addition of talc improved the tensile properties only slightly. In other words, most of the improvement achieved by adding talc was cancelled out by the adverse effect of the compounding itself. Understanding the exact effects of compounding can provide insights into preparing suitable compounding procedures. For example, preparing a high-content talc masterbatch and then diluting it to a lower talc content by simple dry blending can significantly reduce the compounding’s adverse effects.

sec.title: Effect of annealing on tensile properties
sec.p:
Figure 17 shows the specific strength and modulus, strain at break, and the specific toughness of solid and foamed PLA-A and PLA-T samples before and after the annealing process. The effect of annealing on the mechanical properties of the PLA-P samples was found to be similar to that of PLA-A. Therefore, only the PLA-A results are presented here. Both the specific strength and modulus of all the samples increased after annealing by a maximum of 13% and 25%, respectively. The annealing process resulted in increased PLA crystallinity, as shown in Table 3. Increased crystallinity was likely to strengthen the polymer structure and result in increased modulus and strength. Similar results have been observed for PLA blends.31,32 It is noted that the improvement in the specific strength and modulus of the PLA-A and PLA-P samples was slightly greater than that of the PLA-T samples. This was attributed to the greater increase in the crystallinity of the PLA-A and PLA-P samples after annealing compared with that in the PLA-T. At the same time, the increased crystallinity changed the failure behavior of the samples from ductile to relatively brittle, with the strain at break and the specific toughness being significantly reduced. Both the strain at break and the specific toughness were decreased by a maximum of about 40% and 25%, respectively. Figure 17.
Effect of annealing on the tensile properties of solid and foamed PLA-A and PLA-T: (a) specific tensile strength; (b) specific tensile modulus; (c) strain at break, and (d) specific toughness.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Low-pressure structural molding of PLA foams was conducted and characterized. Three different material systems were investigated: as received neat PLA, compounded neat PLA, and PLA compounded with 5 wt.% talc. This was done to assess the sole effects of twin-screw compounding and the addition of talc on the foaming behavior, structural uniformity, crystallization behavior, and mechanical properties of the solid and foam injected PLA samples.

This study demonstrated the procedure and strategies of producing fine-celled PLA foams with a relatively high void fraction (∼30%) and uniform structure. The results revealed that the compounding procedure could cause significant changes in the PLA’s thermal and mechanical properties. These changes were caused not only by the additive but also by the processing itself, and they should be taken carefully into account.

The addition of 5 wt.% talc markedly improved the foaming ability, achieving greater cell density, smaller cell size, and increased structural uniformity throughout the sample. However, the twin-screw compounding did not significantly affect the foaming behavior. Furthermore, the injection flow rate was found to be one of the most influential processing parameters in the injection foam molding. When it was increased, the foaming properties and the structural uniformity also noticeably increased.

The compounding process, addition of talc, and annealing process all increased the PLA’s final crystallinity and consequently affected the mechanical properties. Talc also showed significant toughening effect. The compounding process produced a significant adverse effect and introduced a marked brittleness to the PLA samples. In both the solid and foamed processed PLA samples, this processing effect was more pronounced in the strain at break and specific toughness. The addition of talc had little effect on the PLA’s specific modulus and strength. But, it significantly increased the strain at break and the specific toughness and thus improved the ductility of the solid and foamed processed PLA samples. This improvement was more pronounced in the foamed samples than in the solid ones due to the talc effect in achieving fine-celled uniform foams. Also, the annealing process changed the failure behavior of all solid and foamed samples from ductile to brittle, with an increased modulus and strength and a reduced toughness.

ack.p: The work was financially supported by MITACS Elevate Program. The material was provided by Jed Randall of NatureWorks® LLC, Minnetonka, Minnesota, USA.
